data.title: SA analyst upgrades/downgrades: META, UNH, CSGP, MDLZ
data.description:
Recent analyst actions reveal strategic adjustments among major companies including Meta Platforms (META), which has been upgraded due to promising revenue prospects and an attractive valuation, while Mondelez International (MDLZ) sees an improved outlook as cocoa prices stabilise. Conversely, CoStar Group (CSGP) and UnitedHealth Group (UNH) face downgrades due to concerns over spending efficiency and a challenging market environment, respectively.

Upgrades

  • Meta Platforms (META): Upgrade Hold to Buy by Ahan Vashi. Despite a significant one-time tax charge affecting Q3 earnings, the analyst sees strong core KPIs and a bullish outlook supported by technical and fundamental analysis.

    “Considering Meta’s healthy business performance, reasonable valuation, and constructive technical setup, I am upgrading Meta back to a Buy rating in light of its Q3 2025 earnings dip. … Meta is potentially in the middle of a bullish Wave-5 move as per Elliott Wave Theory, with a target range of $850-1075 per share.”

  • Mondelez International (MDLZ): Upgrade Hold to Buy by Caffital Research. The analyst expects earnings to rebound as cocoa prices begin to moderate, which should alleviate pressure on margins.

    “Cocoa prices have started to moderate due to improved crops, setting up a gradual earnings recovery in the upcoming years. The stock now undervalues Mondelez’s normalized earnings potential, and as such, I upgrade my rating on MDLZ stock to Buy.”

Downgrades

  • CoStar Group (CSGP): Downgrade Buy to Hold by Sandpiper Investment Research. The analyst expresses concerns about high SG&A spending not delivering proportional growth and the company’s lofty valuation.

    “Until management can meaningfully improve margins, get better returns on incremental SG&A dollars spent to drive gross profit growth. CoStar just doesn’t deserve a $30+ billion market cap. ”

  • UnitedHealth Group (UNH): Downgrade Buy to Hold by StockBros Research. While acknowledging good Q3 earnings, the analyst is cautious about ongoing profitability pressures and elevated valuations.

    “Investors buying today can buy UNH at a reasonable price, but it still has to deal with elevated medical utilization, regulatory headwinds, and turnaround work at Optum. Despite the long-term picture still looking good, the urgency to add at these levels is gone.”

data.title: C.H. Robinson surges 20% on management’s bullish 2026 guidance
data.description:
C.H. Robinson Worldwide (CHRW) gained as much as 20% on Thursday following a mixed third-quarter print. Shares of the company were trading 20.34% higher at $ $155.69 during mid-day trading.

The freight transportation firm  posted adjusted earnings of $1.40 per share, beating analysts’ estimates of $1.30. Total revenue came in at $4.13 billion, falling behind the consensus of $4.22 billion.

The third-quarter revenue registered an 11% year-on-year decline, which the company attributed to lower pricing and volume in ocean services, divestiture of the Europe Surface Transportation business, and lower pricing in truckload services.

Total revenues for the North American Surface Transportation (NAST) segment rose 1.1% year over year to $3.0 billion, driven by higher volumes in both truckload and LTL services, partially offset by lower truckload pricing, the company said.

Despite the revenue miss, investors seem encouraged by the management’s bullish outlook.

C.H. Robinson has increased its 2026 operating income target to the range of $965 million to $1.04 billion, with the bottom end equating to about $6 of earnings per share. The company continues to expect full-year 2025 personnel expenses above the midpoint of $1.3 billion to $1.4 billion and SG&A expenses above the midpoint of $550 million to $600 million.

"We originally expected to increase our 2026 operating income by $350 million to $450 million versus our 2023 adjusted operating income of $553 million. Today, we increased that expectation by roughly $50 million despite market dynamics that have created greater headwinds than we originally anticipated," CFO Damon Lee said during the earnings call.

The stock has appreciated by nearly 49%, year-to-date, while in the past year it has soared by 42.17%.

data.title: Ametek raises full-year EPS guidance to $7.32–$7.37 as orders and margins hit records amid strong acquisition performance
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: AMETEK, Inc. (AME) Q3 2025

Management View

  • CEO David Zapico stated AMETEK "delivered outstanding results in the third quarter with double-digit growth in sales, orders, operating profit and diluted earnings per share." He highlighted record sales of $1.89 billion (up 11% year-over-year), organic sales growth of 4%, and acquisitions adding 6 points. Orders reached a record $1.97 billion, with organic orders up 7% and a backlog of $3.54 billion. Zapico emphasized "outstanding margin expansion and earnings well ahead of our expectations," leading to an increased full-year earnings guidance.

  • Zapico detailed group results: Electronic Instruments Group (EIG) achieved record sales of $1.25 billion, with acquisitions contributing significantly. Electromechanical Group (EMG) posted record sales of $646 million and operating income of $164 million, up 25% year-over-year, with broad-based strength across businesses. He underscored recent acquisitions—FARO, Virtek, Kern, and Paragon—as integrating well and contributing strong results.

  • Strategic capital deployment remains focused on acquisitions. Zapico said, "We are managing a strong pipeline of attractive acquisition candidates and expect to be active in pursuing strategic opportunities going forward." He also noted a planned incremental $90 million investment for organic growth initiatives in 2025.

  • New product innovations were highlighted: Virtek Vision's AI-powered inspection system, NSI-MI Technologies' Vector Digital Receiver, and Rauland's Responder platform, which won the MedTech Breakthrough Award for Best Clinical Administration hardware device.

  • Zapico addressed trade environment volatility, stating, "We remain vigilant in monitoring developments and proactively managing potential impacts," with mitigation including targeted pricing and supply chain modifications.

  • CFO Dalip Puri reported, "Third quarter general and administrative expenses were $28 million or 1.5% of sales, essentially in line with last year's third quarter." He added that free cash flow was $420 million, and free cash flow conversion reached 113%.

Outlook

  • Zapico stated, "We continue to expect full year sales to be up mid-single digits on a percentage basis compared to 2024." Full-year diluted EPS guidance was raised to a range of $7.32 to $7.37, up from the previous range of $7.06 to $7.20. For Q4, sales are anticipated to be up approximately 10% with EPS in the $1.90 to $1.95 range.

  • Zapico added, "Fourth quarter earnings growth would be 6% to 9% adjusting for last year's lower-than-normal tax rate."

Financial Results

  • Third quarter sales reached a record $1.89 billion, with operating income at a record $496 million, and EBITDA at $592 million. Diluted EPS was $1.89, up 14% year-over-year.

  • EIG sales were $1.25 billion; EMG sales were $646 million. Operating margins for EIG (excluding acquisitions) reached 30.4%, while EMG operating margins rose to 25.4%.

  • Operating cash flow was $441 million, with $420 million in free cash flow. Capex for the quarter was $21 million.

  • At quarter end, total debt stood at $2.5 billion, up from $2.1 billion at the end of 2024, primarily due to the FARO acquisition. The company repurchased approximately 800,000 shares during the quarter.

Q&A

  • Deane Dray, RBC: Asked about platform and regional performance, with a focus on Paragon. Zapico responded that Process segment sales were up low teens, with strong project pipelines despite trade-related delays. Aerospace & Defense showed low double-digit organic sales growth, and Power & Industrial benefited from grid modernization demand. He also discussed regional trends, noting strong Europe performance and a decline in China due to tariff impacts.

  • Matt Summerville, D.A. Davidson: Sought details on Paragon and Process optimism. Zapico explained Paragon delivered double-digit order growth and successful cost restructuring. He expressed optimism for Process, citing improving trends outside China.

  • Andrew Obin, BofA: Asked about Europe and order progression. Zapico described broad-based European strength and noted September was the strongest month for orders and sales.

  • Christopher Snyder, Morgan Stanley: Queried Q4 top line guide and Industrial & Power trends. Zapico attributed Power growth to backup power systems for data centers and noted industrial strength. CFO Puri explained FX is not expected to impact Q4 results.

  • Other analysts addressed topics including the FARO integration, Automation segment growth, price versus cost, EMG margins, short-cycle exposure, and the M&A pipeline. Zapico and Puri reiterated strong order momentum, pricing power offsetting inflation/tariffs, and ongoing operational execution.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts expressed confidence in the results, frequently congratulating management and focusing on execution, order trends, and segment momentum, with a slightly positive to positive tone.

  • Management maintained a confident and upbeat tone throughout, frequently citing "outstanding" results and "record" performance. During Q&A, Zapico emphasized confidence in guidance and strategic direction and used assertive language such as "we are very bullish" and "I couldn't be more pleased."

  • Compared to the previous quarter, sentiment has shifted further toward optimism, especially due to increased guidance and strong order momentum.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Full-year EPS guidance was raised from $7.06–$7.20 to $7.32–$7.37, reflecting improved confidence and higher Q3 performance.

  • Organic order growth accelerated (7% in Q3 vs. flat in Q2), and overall sales growth increased (11% in Q3 vs. 2.5% in Q2).

  • Margin expansion was stronger, with EMG operating margins up 250 basis points year-over-year, compared to 210 basis points in Q2.

  • Management tone was more confident, highlighting stronger contributions from recent acquisitions and new product launches.

  • Analysts focused more on granular performance by segment and regional trends, with less emphasis on macro uncertainty than previously.

Risks and Concerns

  • Zapico mentioned "macroeconomic uncertainty, given the ongoing trade conflicts," and continued monitoring of trade dynamics and demand timing.

  • Management outlined mitigation strategies including targeted pricing, supply chain modifications, and leveraging a global manufacturing footprint.

  • Tariff renegotiation and pricing delays in China remain a challenge, though management sees strong long-term positions in the region.

Final Takeaway

AMETEK showcased a robust third quarter, achieving record sales and earnings, strong margin expansion, and significant order growth. The company raised its full-year earnings outlook as recent acquisitions contributed meaningfully and operational execution remained strong. Management emphasized strategic capital deployment and innovation while acknowledging ongoing trade and macroeconomic uncertainties. With record backlog and a healthy balance sheet, AMETEK remains positioned for continued growth and value creation.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: TotalEnergies CEO says Mozambique LNG project cost remains $20B
data.description:
TotalEnergies (TTE) plans to restart its Mozambique LNG project quickly with a budget at $20.5 billion, CEO Patrick Pouyanne said Thursday, adding that media reports incorrectly interpreted his letter to Mozambique's president which requests approval for a $4.5 billion cost increase related to the project's four-year pause.

"I want to be very clear and strong on this point: The budget was ~$15.5 billion previously, $4.5 billion is what we've spent in these past years. So the total is not $25 billion but $20.5 billion," Pouyanne said on the company's earnings conference call, Reuters reported.

Oil markets are underestimating the impact of the latest round of sanctions on Russia, which are starting to affect flows, the CEO also said, according to Bloomberg.

Premiums are rising as countries seek to reroute shipments and find a way to bring more expensive crude oil and refined products to different corners of the globe, Pouyanne said.

TotalEnergies (TTE) reported Q3 adjusted net income fell slightly to $3.98 billion from $4.07 billion in the year-earlier quarter, and revenues fell 7.6% Y/Y to $43.85 billion, compared to net profit of $4.03 billion and revenues of $42.54 billion according to consensus estimates compiled by Visible Alpha.

data.title: META’s selloff affects over 600 ETFs, but these 10 funds have the most exposure
data.description:
Shares of Meta Platforms (META) sank sharply on Thursday, dropping more than 12% after the social media giant reported earnings that fell short of expectations.

The steep decline in META weighed heavily not only on its own stock but also on the broader tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite (COMP:IND) and rattled investor sentiment across multiple exchange-traded funds with significant META exposure. 

The California-based tech giant is currently held in 637 ETFs, collectively owning over 309 million shares. The pullback underscores META’s outsized influence on tech-focused markets, highlighting how disappointing results from a single mega cap can ripple across the broader investment landscape. 

Outlined below are Wall Street’s 10 ETFs that have the largest allocation towards META.

No. 1: GraniteShares 2x Long META Daily ETF (FBL), 99.96% allocation.

No. 2: Global X PureCap MSCI Communication Services ETF (GXPC), 26.45% allocation. 

No. 3: iShares Global Comm Services ETF (IXP), 21.93% allocation. 

No. 4: Fidelity MSCI Communication Services Index ETF (FCOM), 20.21% allocation.

No. 5: Vanguard Communication Services ETF (VOX), 20.02% allocation. 

No. 6: Roundhill META WeeklyPay ETF (METW), 19.93% allocation. 

No. 7: Communication Services Select Sector SPDR Fund (XLC), 15.21% allocation. 

No. 8: Direxion Daily Magnificent 7 Bull 2X Shares (QQQU), 11.98% allocation. 

No. 9: Direxion Daily META Bull 2X Shares (METU), 11.49% allocation. 

No. 10: ProShares Ultra Communication Services (LTL), 10.69% allocation. 

Meta Platforms Performance and Ratings

  • 1-Month: -9.6%.
  • 6-Month: +20.1%.
  • Year-to-Date: +12.5%.
  • SA Quant Rating: 3.47.
  • SA Analyst Rating: 4.15.
  • Wall Street Rating: 4.58.

data.title: Wall Street observes mixed moves after key big tech earnings and U.S.-China trade talks
data.description:
Wall Street is mixed on Thursday as Meta (META) and Microsoft (MSFT) earnings failed to impress investors. Market focus now has shifted to Apple (AAPL) and Amazon (AMZN) ahead of their reports, while traders also digest the latest updates from U.S.-China trade talks.

Falling the hardest has been the tech focused Nasdaq Composite (COMP:IND) which was last lower by 0.9%. At the same time, the benchmark S&P 500 (SP500) was in the red by 0.2%, and the blue-chip Dow (DJI) was higher by 0.7%. 

From a sector point of view, seven of the 11 S&P segments are trading up in the green with Financials leading the way. At the other end of the spectrum, the Info Tech space has suffered the most so far. 

U.S. Treasury yields inched higher as the longer-end U.S. 10-year Treasury yield (US10Y) pushed up 1 basis point to 4.08% and the shorter-end U.S. 2-year Treasury yield (US2Y) moved up by 1 basis point to 3.60%.

Earnings data from Meta Platforms (META) and Microsoft (MSFT) have dampened market momentum with META down 12.5% and MSFT lower by 3%. At the same time, Alphabet (GOOG)(GOOGL) has responded positively to its latest earnings figures as it has climbed 4.8%.

In the day ahead, traders will get more tech earnings, with Apple (AAPL) and Amazon (AMZN) set to report after the closing bell.

"We expect Amazon to miss expectations in its Thursday earnings report, and this is why we believed they pre-announced so many layoffs this week. Amazon's stock has underperformed and it's not as good of a business as many on Wall Street think," David Trainer, CEO of New Constructs said.

"We expect Apple to beat Wall Street's earnings expectations on the back of strong iPhone 17 sales. These strong iPhone sales show that even in this AI world, we still need a strong network of physical devices to drive AI adoption and use, and Apple is at the center of that, even if their AI strategy is minimal," Trainer added.

U.S. President Donald Trump announced a one-year agreement with China covering rare earths and critical minerals, while also halving fentanyl-related tariffs on Beijing (from 20% to 10%), effective immediately, following his meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping in South Korea on Thursday.

"Despite its brevity, it appears that there was some progress in U.S.-China trade negotiations. But perhaps not quite as much as President Trump had signaled earlier this week...There was no word on either the future of Taiwan or TikTok. So, summing up the conclusion to this historic meeting: underwhelming," David Morrison, senior market analyst at Trade Nation, said. 

Furthermore, the Fed on Wednesday reduced its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points to 3.75%-4.00%, its second straight cut, as it seeks to ease off the brakes in an effort to protect the labor market.

data.title: Aptiv outlines $31B bookings target and EDS spin-off strategy amid trade and supply chain headwinds
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Aptiv PLC (APTV) Q3 2025

Management View

  • Kevin P. Clark, President, Chairman & CEO, stated that Aptiv “capitalized on the underlying growth in vehicle production in North America and Asia Pacific, while also continuing to experience strong revenue growth in nonautomotive markets.” He highlighted the company’s “resilient operating model” and noted that Aptiv is “progressing as planned with the separation of our Electrical Distribution Systems business by the end of the first quarter of 2026.”

  • Clark reported, “Our third quarter bookings of $8.4 billion validate customer confidence and strong market demand for our portfolio of advanced technologies.” He further commented that “revenues increased 6% to $5.2 billion,” and operating income “increased 10% to $654 million.” Earnings per share reached a record $2.17.

  • On strategic milestones, Clark remarked, “We continue to expect roughly $31 billion in new business bookings for the year, although timing of some program awards slated for the fourth quarter could shift into 2026.”

  • Varun Laroyia, Executive VP & CFO, stated, “Revenues were a record $5.2 billion, up 6% on an adjusted basis. Adjusted EBITDA and operating income grew 9% and 10%, respectively, also reaching record levels. And operating income margin expanded 30 basis points, primarily driven by strong volume flow-through, manufacturing performance and the benefits from our ongoing cost initiatives.” He noted an operating cash flow of $584 million and capital expenditures of $143 million.

Outlook

  • Clark announced an updated 2025 outlook: “We’re raising our full year 2025 guidance, reflecting the strength of our third quarter results, partially offset by recent customer-specific production disruptions and an outlook for the fourth quarter that prudently incorporates an element of conservatism to reflect the amplified trade tensions beginning to impact semiconductor supply chains.”

  • Laroyia provided specifics: “Our full year revenue outlook of $20.3 billion at the midpoint continues to reflect an adjusted growth rate of 2%. Adjusted EBITDA and operating income are expected to be approximately $3.22 billion and $2.45 billion at the midpoint, each up 4% versus the prior year.” Adjusted EPS is estimated in the range of $7.55 to $7.85, up 23% at the midpoint.

  • For Q4, Laroyia said, “Our fourth quarter guidance implies a revenue growth of 1% on an adjusted basis at the midpoint... operating income margin of 11.8% at the midpoint.”

Financial Results

  • Aptiv reported third quarter revenues of $5.2 billion, operating income of $654 million, and EPS of $2.17. Operating cash flow totaled $584 million, with $250 million deployed for share repurchases and debt paydown.

  • Segment results included flat revenues in Advanced Safety and User Experience (AS & UX), 6% revenue growth in Engineered Components Group (ECG), and 11% revenue growth in Electrical Distribution Systems (EDS).

  • A noncash goodwill impairment charge of $648 million for Wind River was recorded, attributed to “slower than originally expected growth in the business over 2023 and 2024, owing to delays in 5G adoption and the launch of software-defined vehicles.”

Q&A

  • Chris McNally, Evercore: Questioned the $80 million Q4 revenue headwind and regional impacts. Clark clarified, “It does encompass some volume impact associated with the facility issue or the facility fire in Oswego... there are other unique customer-specific situations with OEMs, including OEMs in Europe that are impacting our outlook for European production.”

  • McNally followed with concerns on chip supply and political risk. Clark replied, “It is a political issue between the Dutch government and China... product is flowing in China. So as we sit here today, it does not -- we're certainly not being impacted... we have roughly 3 months of inventory. We were confident we won't impact any OEMs in the fourth quarter.”

  • Joseph Spak, UBS: Asked about Q4 margin guidance and copper prices. Laroyia responded, “Three key pieces... flow-through on the weaker volumes... the one customer recovery... and then the final one... elevated copper prices.” Clark emphasized, “The year-over-year impact from an FX commodity standpoint is significant... north of 100 basis points on a year-over-year.”

  • Dan Levy, Barclays: Sought clarity on regional growth dynamics. Clark explained, “The bigger impacts for us in Europe and China tend to be tied to specific OEM volume issues... In China, the big impact for us this year were those 3 program cancellations that we talked about for NIO and Zeekr in the second quarter.”

  • James Picariello, BNP Paribas: Asked about active safety and user experience segments. Clark indicated, “Active safety growth in the quarter and back half of the year, we would expect that to be low single digits versus first half of the year kind of high single digits.” He added, “User experience... back half of the year will be down low double digits. We were down 10% in the third quarter.”

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts pressed on supply chain disruptions, the impact of geopolitical trade issues, and margin headwinds, indicating a slightly negative to neutral tone, especially regarding earnings sustainability and guidance conservatism.

  • Management maintained a confident but cautious tone. Clark stated, “We’re confident we won't impact any OEMs in the fourth quarter,” and stressed proactive risk management. During prepared remarks, management tone was assertive and optimistic, while Q&A responses were more measured and sometimes defensive, especially when addressing uncertainties.

  • Compared to the previous quarter, both analysts and management appeared incrementally more concerned about external risks and the outlook for Q4, with analysts seeking more detail on downside scenarios.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • The updated 2025 revenue outlook was raised from $20.15 billion in Q2 to $20.3 billion in Q3, with guidance for adjusted EPS also increased. Management attributed this to stronger-than-expected Q3 performance but noted increased conservatism for Q4, reflecting new supply chain and customer disruptions.

  • Strategic focus shifted more explicitly to the EDS spin-off, with a timeline reiterated for Q1 2026.

  • Analysts in both quarters focused on China mix, margin headwinds, and non-automotive growth, but Q3 featured more questions about geopolitical risks and supply chain resilience.

  • Management confidence remained solid in prepared remarks but was more qualified during Q&A, particularly around production outlook and margin impacts.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management cited “recent customer-specific production disruptions” and “amplified trade tensions beginning to impact semiconductor supply chains.”

  • Clark acknowledged, “the macro environment remains very dynamic with changing geopolitical trends, regulations and trade policies as well as customer-specific challenges, all of which are difficult to precisely forecast.”

  • Analysts repeatedly raised concerns about Q4 headwinds, supply chain risk, and the potential impact of political disputes on semiconductor supply, and sought reassurance on margin sustainability amid commodity and FX headwinds.

Final Takeaway

Aptiv’s third quarter showcased record financial performance and robust bookings, as management raised full-year guidance while acknowledging a more cautious stance for the fourth quarter due to supply chain disruptions, customer-specific issues, and global trade tensions. The company reaffirmed its commitment to the EDS spin-off, expects approximately $31 billion in new business bookings for the year, and highlighted continued growth in non-automotive markets. While management voiced confidence in Aptiv’s operational resilience and long-term prospects, the Q&A revealed heightened caution from both analysts and executives regarding near-term risks and external uncertainties.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript
